j> Hi, I was wondering in what way was the Java Reflection library 
j> important for the creation of JUnit. Thanks...

In short, reflection makes it easier to write and run the tests.

There is a class named TestSuite which uses reflection to build an
object for all of the test methods on a test class.  In languages
without reflection, the programmer has to add register each test method
with a suite manually.

It is a pretty tedious process, and it is also prone to error.
Sometimes people who are using the C++ port of JUnit look at a test
that should fail and realize that the reason that it doesn't is
because the registration of the method was accidently deleted.
